topics: History taking
Physical examination
Assessment procedures
Clinical reasoning
Clinical judgments
Treatment and evaluation of patients with medical and neurological conditions such as Stroke, Parkinson's disease, Diabetes mellitus, Guillain-Barre syndrome
Communication of management plan and other information with patients
Goal setting
objectives: Take history, carry out physical examination and other relevant assessment procedures on patients with medical and neurological conditions
Demonstrate skills in clinical reasoning and in making clinical judgments in different medical and neurological conditions
Demonstrate skills in communicating management plan and other information with patients
Demonstrate skills in managing and evaluating patients with common medical and neurological conditions seen in physiotherapy
aim: The aim of this clinical posting is to provide students with practical experience in physiotherapy for medical and neurological conditions. By the end of the posting, students should be able to demonstrate skills in history taking, physical examination, clinical reasoning, communication with patients, and management of common medical and neurological conditions seen in physiotherapy.

topics: History taking
Physical examination
Assessment procedures
Clinical reasoning
Clinical judgments
Treatment and evaluation of patients with head and spinal cord injuries and other conditions requiring neurosurgery such as post excision of tumor within the skull
Communication of management plan and other information with patients
objectives: Take history, carry out physical examination and other relevant assessment procedures on patients with head and spinal cord injuries and other conditions requiring neurosurgery
Demonstrate skills in clinical reasoning and in making clinical judgments in head and spinal cord injuries and other conditions requiring neurosurgery
Demonstrate skills in communicating management plan and other information with patients
Demonstrate skills in managing and evaluating patients with head and spinal cord injuries and other conditions requiring neurosurgery
aim: The aim of this clinical posting is to provide students with practical experience in physiotherapy for patients undergoing neurosurgery. By the end of the posting, students should be able to demonstrate skills in history taking, physical examination, clinical reasoning, communication with patients, and management of patients with head and spinal cord injuries and other conditions requiring neurosurgery.

topics: Medical imaging facilities and their preferential uses (radiographs, ultrasound scan, CT scan, MRI)
Reading and interpretation of radiographs for common conditions managed by physiotherapy
Terminologies in radiology and their recognition in radiographs
Reading and interpretation of CT scan and MRI with emphasis on diagnosis of disorders of brain and the spine
Clinical values of other specialized procedures (myelogram, bronchogram, angiogram, barium meals, etc.)
objectives: Read and interpret radiographs, CT scan and MRI of conditions commonly seen in physiotherapy
Demonstrate understanding of terminologies in radiology and their recognition in radiographs
Interpret CT scan and MRI with emphasis on diagnosis of disorders of brain and the spine
Understand the clinical values of other specialized procedures
aim: The aim of this course is to provide students with the necessary skills to read and interpret medical imaging results commonly used in physiotherapy practice. By the end of the course, students should be able to interpret radiographs, CT scans, and MRIs of conditions such as fractures, osteoarthritis, spinal disorders, and brain abnormalities.

topics: Relationships between physical and psychological disorders
Psychopathology of pain
Common mental disorders associated with painful conditions
Somatoform and factitious disorders
Basic psychological therapies relevant to physiotherapy
Behavioural and emotional disorders associated with common physiotherapy conditions
objectives: Explain the relationship between physical and psychological disorders
Describe mental disorders associated with painful conditions
Identify somatoform and factitious disorders
Describe behavioural and emotional disorders associated with common physiotherapy conditions
aim: The aim of this course is to provide students with an understanding of the relationship between physical and psychological disorders, as well as common mental disorders associated with painful conditions. Students will also learn about somatoform and factitious disorders, along with basic psychological therapies relevant to physiotherapy.

topics: Assessment of patients before and after surgery
Management of patients before, during, and after surgical operations
Observation of surgical procedures in the theatre
Monitoring and management of patients during immediate post-operative periods
Monitoring and management of patients during admission
objectives: Describe assessment of patients before and after surgery
Outline the management of patients before, during, and after surgical operations
aim: The aim of this course is to provide students with practical exposure to surgical procedures and patient care in various surgical units. Students will learn about the assessment and management of patients before, during, and after surgery, as well as observe surgical procedures and participate in post-operative care.

coursetitle: Electrotherapy III: Direct , Low & Medium Frequency Stimulating Currents & Electro-diagnosis
topics: Direct/galvanic current-electrical parameters and application - iontophoresis (including treatment of hyperhidrosis)
Low frequency currents - faradic type, interrupted direct, sinusoidal currents. Principles and methods of application
Therapeutic uses (nerve stimulation, stimulation of denervated muscles), indications, contraindications for, dangers of, precautionary measures
Electro-diagnosis (strength - duration curves, nerve conduction test, EMG)

Electro-analgesia - revision of pain modulation (pain gate theory). Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), interferential currents, diadynamic currents, high voltage pulsed galvanic current, Russian/Rebox currents
objectives: Describe the electrical parameters of direct, low and medium frequency currents

Discuss basic principles governing the application and uses of direct, low and medium frequency stimulating currents (iontophoresis, nerve and muscle stimulation, electro-diagnosis and electro-analgesia)
Enumerate indications, dangers and contraindications of low and medium frequency stimulating currents
aim: The aim of this course is to provide students with advanced knowledge and skills in the application of direct, low, and medium frequency stimulating currents and electrodiagnosis. By the end of the course, students should be able to describe the electrical parameters of these currents, discuss their applications and uses, and enumerate their indications, dangers, and contraindications.

topics: Practical aspects of PST410
objectives: Demonstrate skills in selecting and applying appropriate stimulating currents for different purposes and conditions
Demonstrate skills in electro-diagnosis
aim: The aim of this course is to provide students with practical experience in selecting and applying appropriate stimulating currents for different purposes and conditions, as well as in electro-diagnosis. By the end of the course, students should be able to demonstrate proficiency in these skills.

topics: Definitions of diagnosis, physical diagnosis, medical diagnosis and differential diagnosis
Importance of physical diagnosis in physiotherapy
Overview of clinical reasoning skills and clinical decision making
Models of clinical reasoning process
Overview of clinical decision making skills
Drawing inferences from clinical data (history taking, health measurement, physical examination, vital signs, end-feels etc)
Specific provocative movement tests and physical diagnosis in musculoskeletal conditions
Physical diagnosis in neurological, paediatric, cardiopulmonary and other conditions
Case studies/simulation for clinical reasoning
objectives: Describe and differentiate among different models of clinical reasoning process
Demonstrate competence in differential diagnosis and clinical decision making in some musculoskeletal conditions requiring physiotherapy
Demonstrate competence in differential diagnosis and clinical decision making in some cardiopulmonary, paediatric and other conditions requiring physiotherapy
aim: The aim of this course is to equip students with the knowledge and skills necessary for clinical reasoning and physical diagnosis in physiotherapy practice. By the end of the course, students should be able to describe different models of clinical reasoning, demonstrate competence in differential diagnosis and clinical decision making for various musculoskeletal, cardiopulmonary, paediatric, and other conditions.

topics: Historical background
Hydrodynamic laws (Archimedes Law, Pascal's Law, Surface tension, etc.)
Body immersion and weightlessness
Types of therapeutic pools
Whirlpools and baths
Pool accessories
Therapeutic pool environment (temperature, pH, humidity, ventilation, water hygiene)
Methods of exercise in therapeutic pools (conventional method and Bad-Ragaz method)
Physiological effects, therapeutic uses, indications, contraindications, dangers, and safety measures
Application to specific conditions (paralytic, spastic, rheumatic, orthopedic)
Pool plants components, care, and maintenance
Advantages and disadvantages of exercises in water versus exercises on land
objectives: Explain the advantages of exercises in water over exercises on land
Explain the application of hydrodynamic laws to hydrotherapy
Describe basic methods of exercises in water
Instruct patients in exercises in a therapeutic pool
Select appropriate hydrotherapy medium for different parts of the body
aim: The aim of this course is to provide students with an understanding of hydrotherapy principles and techniques. By the end of the course, students should be able to explain the advantages of exercises in water, apply hydrodynamic laws to hydrotherapy, describe methods of exercises in water, instruct patients in therapeutic pool exercises, and select appropriate hydrotherapy mediums for different body parts.

topics: Fractures: definition, classification, complications, healing (delayed, mal, and non-union)
Dislocations
General principles of management of fractures and dislocations
General management of fractures (closed and open reductions, immobilizations, internal and external fixations) and dislocations (reductions and immobilizations)
Physiotherapy management during and post-immobilization including training in assisted walking
General management of acute and chronic soft tissue injuries (muscular, tendinous, and ligamentous injuries, tendinitis, tenosynovitis, fasciitis, ACL repairs, meniscal repairs, etc.)
Burns: types, severity calculation, methods of management, complications, cardiovascular implications of extensive burns, role of physiotherapy before and after healing, role of pressure garment
Amputation: Immediate post-operative, pre-prosthetic and post-prosthetic care
Whiplash injuries, fracture & dislocation of the spinal column
objectives: Describe the general and physiotherapy management of fractures and dislocations
Describe physiotherapy management of soft tissue injuries
Explain the role of physiotherapy in the care of patients with burns and amputations
aim: The aim of this course is to provide students with an understanding of skeletal and soft tissue injuries and their physiotherapy management. By the end of the course, students should be able to describe the management of fractures, dislocations, and soft tissue injuries, as well as explain the role of physiotherapy in the care of patients with burns and amputations.

topics: Joint disorders: osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, gout, temporomandibular joint disorders, haemophilic arthritis
Spinal disorders: neck pain, back pain, sacroiliac joint pain, cervical and lumbar spondylosis (intervertebral disc lesions), spinal stenosis, spondylolisthesis, ankylosing spondylitis
Infectious conditions: septic arthritis, tuberculous arthritis, osteomyelitis
Bone disorders: osteoporosis, osteomalacia, Paget's disease, etc.
Musculoskeletal deformities: scoliosis, kyphosis, kyphoscoliosis
Myofascial pain syndrome
Fibromyalgia
Connective tissue disorders: polymyositis, systemic lupus erythematosus
Joint replacements (hip and knee), acute care (including precautions and safety) following surgeries (special consideration for old/elderly patients)
objectives: Describe the pathological basis, aetiology, and clinical features of common orthopaedic conditions
Describe assessment procedures for common orthopaedic conditions seen in physiotherapy
Describe physiotherapy management of common orthopaedic conditions seen in physiotherapy
aim: The aim of this course is to provide students with an understanding of common orthopaedic conditions, including their pathological basis, clinical features, assessment procedures, and physiotherapy management. By the end of the course, students should be able to describe and assess common orthopaedic conditions and implement appropriate physiotherapy interventions.

topics: Motor development during the first five years of life: important considerations in motor development (growth/maturation of the brain after birth, environment), sequence, principles of development
Introduction to motor control theories; reflex development and testing
Cerebral palsy: definition, aetiology, clinical features, and classification; assessment; treatment approaches (Neuro-developmental Therapy/Bobath's method)
Spina Bifida
Mental retardation (Downs Syndrome)
Autism
Acute flaccid paralysis: poliomyelitis, sciatic nerve injection palsy, Guillain-Barre Syndrome
Brachial plexus injuries: Erb's palsy, Klumpke's paralysis, Duchenne Klumpke's paralysis
Muscular dystrophies
objectives: Describe the sequence, principles of, and factors influencing movement development during the first five years of life
Describe the pathological basis, aetiology, and clinical features of neuromotor and neuromuscular conditions in children
Describe the assessment procedures for neuromotor and neuromuscular conditions in children
Describe physiotherapy management of neuromotor and neuromuscular conditions in children
aim: The aim of this course is to provide students with an understanding of paediatric physiotherapy, focusing on motor development during the first five years of life and the assessment and management of neuromotor and neuromuscular conditions in children. By the end of the course, students should be able to describe the development of motor skills in children, assess neuromotor and neuromuscular conditions, and implement appropriate physiotherapy interventions for paediatric patients.

topics: Definition of health measurement
Population and individual health statistics
Physiotherapy measurements and clinical decision making
Outcomes assessment
Identification of outcomes
Selection of outcome measures
Methods of integrating outcomes assessment into clinical practice
Psychometric properties: validity, reliability, and utility

Measurement of specific variables: vital signs, pain, disability, functional performance, anthropometric variables, physical fitness measurement (stress test), lung function tests, motor function tests
objectives: Explain the importance of health measurement to clinical decision making
Identify and measure outcomes in conditions commonly seen in physiotherapy
Describe psychometric properties of health measuring instruments
aim: The aim of this course is to equip students with the knowledge and skills necessary to understand and apply health measurement and outcomes assessment in physiotherapy practice. By the end of the course, students should be able to explain the significance of health measurement in clinical decision making, identify and measure outcomes relevant to physiotherapy practice, and evaluate the psychometric properties of health measuring instruments.

topics: Orthotics
Indications, contraindications, dangers, and precautionary measures of orthotic devices
Types of orthotic devices: AFO, KAFO, HKAFO, THKAFO, insoles, cock-up splints, cervical collars, lumbar corsets, Boston brace, and other braces for correction of scoliosis
Materials for fabrication of orthotic devices: Plaster of Paris (POP), Scotch cast, Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC)
Fabrication of simple orthotic devices: night splint, knee extension splint/back slab, cock-up splint, etc.
Prescription and criteria for selection of orthoses
Prosthetics
Overview of types of prostheses
Physiotherapy in amputee rehabilitation: patient education on care, maintenance, and uses of prostheses; dangers, complications, and contraindications
Practical stump bandaging
Care, uses, and prescription of wheelchairs
One-week posting in plaster techniques
objectives: Correctly prescribe orthotic devices for different conditions
Demonstrate competence in fabricating simple orthotic devices
Correctly prescribe the right types of prostheses for different types of amputations
Perform stump bandaging
aim: The aim of this course is to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to prescribe, fabricate, and utilize orthotic and prosthetic devices in physiotherapy practice. By the end of the course, students should be able to correctly prescribe orthotic devices for various conditions, demonstrate proficiency in fabricating simple orthotic devices, prescribe appropriate prostheses for different types of amputations, and perform stump bandaging effectively.

coursetitle: Seminars on Issues in Health Care
topics: International Health: definitions and classifications
ICD & ICF
Evidence-based practice
Determinants of health and health promotion
The Nigerian health environment and policies
Individual and population health statistics
Evidence-based decision making and practice
Healthcare of selected populations (women, children, and the elderly)
Ethical issues in general clinical practice
Ethical issues in physiotherapy practice
Public and private financing of health services
National Health Insurance Scheme
HIV/AIDS
Euthanasia in Nigeria
objectives: Acquire skills for seminar presentation (search, collate information, and make presentations)
Discuss current issues in health care
aim: The aim of this course is to provide students with an understanding of various issues in health care, both locally and globally. Through seminars and discussions, students will acquire the skills necessary for effective presentation and engage in critical discussions on current topics in health care, including international health, evidence-based practice, ethical issues, healthcare financing, and specific health concerns in Nigeria such as HIV/AIDS and euthanasia.

topics: Research in physiotherapy: focus on the 21st-century research
Identification of research problems
Literature search and review: peripheral and core literature, electronic search engines, importance of meta-analysis, use of literature to guide research
Research designs and sampling methods
Variables: independent & dependent
Data collection, storage, analysis, and presentation
Referencing styles
Manuscript preparation for dissertation and journal publication
objectives: Identify research problems
Describe what literature search and review entail
Describe different research designs and sampling methods
Describe the process of investigating a research problem
aim: The aim of this course is to equip students with the knowledge and skills necessary to conduct research in the field of physiotherapy. By focusing on contemporary research methodologies, students will learn how to identify research problems, conduct literature searches, select appropriate research designs and sampling methods, collect and analyze data, and present research findings. Additionally, students will learn about referencing styles and manuscript preparation for dissertation and journal publication.

topics: Overview of respiratory system
Management of patients with respiratory conditions using problem-oriented medical system
Subjective assessment: breathlessness, wheeze, cough, sputum
Objective assessment: auscultation, spirometry, chest shapes and movement, breathing pattern, chest radiography, blood gas analysis and implication for management
Principles of management and outcomes measurement in respiratory care

Physiotherapy techniques: active cycle of breathing, glossopharyngeal breathing, forced expiratory technique, manual hyperventilation, breathing control, airway clearance techniques and adjunct, non-invasive ventilation, basic life support
Management of specific respiratory conditions: COPD, asthma, bronchiectasis, pulmonary edema, pulmonary tuberculosis, carcinomas, post-surgical conditions e.g. lobectomy, thoracotomy, pneumonectomy
Pulmonary rehabilitation and reconditioning
Health education and promotion: smoking cessation, nutrition, and other lifestyle modifications
Paediatric respiratory care
objectives: Describe the workings of the respiratory system and function
Describe the relationship between the cardiovascular system and respiratory conditions
Explain the underlying principles in the physiotherapy management of respiratory conditions
Outline physiotherapy management for patients with respiratory conditions
aim: The aim of PST421 is to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of respiratory conditions and their physiotherapy management. By covering topics such as the overview of the respiratory system, subjective and objective assessments, principles of management, and specific respiratory conditions, students will develop the knowledge and skills necessary to assess, treat, and manage patients with respiratory conditions effectively. Additionally, the course aims to equip students with the ability to educate patients on health promotion strategies and lifestyle modifications to improve respiratory health.

topics: Introduction to neurology and neurological rehabilitation
Philosophical basis of traditional approaches to neuro-rehabilitation
Current motor control theory and comparison to traditional theories
Aetiology, pathological basis, and clinical features of neurological conditions
Treatment plans for neurological conditions
Epidemiology of neurological disorders
Upper and lower motor neuron disorders
Traditional approaches to neuro-rehabilitation (e.g., PNF, Brunstroms, Bobath, Rood)
Modern approaches to neuro-rehabilitation (neuroplasticity, neurodynamics, neuroadaptation)
Types, causes, and management of peripheral nerve lesions (e.g., Bell's palsy, sciatic nerve palsy, gun-shot injuries)
Medical and physiotherapy management of lesions within the skull (e.g., head injuries, stroke, space-occupying lesions)
The Rehabilitation Team
Assessment tools and outcome measures in neurological physiotherapy
objectives: Describe the philosophical basis of traditional approaches to neuro-rehabilitation
Explain the current motor control theory and compare it to traditional theories
Describe the aetiology, pathological basis, and clinical features of neurological conditions
Outline treatment plans for neurological conditions
aim: PST422 aims to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of neurology and neurological rehabilitation. By covering topics such as traditional and modern approaches to neuro-rehabilitation, motor control theory, and neurological conditions, students will develop the knowledge and skills necessary to assess, treat, and manage patients with neurological disorders effectively. Additionally, the course aims to familiarize students with assessment tools and outcome measures used in neurological physiotherapy and the interdisciplinary nature of rehabilitation teams.

topics: Flaccid paralysis in children
Orthopaedic problems in childhood
Congenital foot deformities
Congenital hip dislocations
Osteogenesis Imperfecta
Torticolis
Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis
Muscular dystrophies
Cardiorespiratory disorders in children
Cystic fibrosis
Asthma
Rheumatic fever
objectives: Describe the aetiology, pathological basis, and clinical features of paediatric conditions
Explain how to assess children with the conditions listed
Outline treatment plans for paediatric conditions
aim: PST423 focuses on expanding students' understanding of paediatric physiotherapy by covering a range of paediatric conditions and their assessment, management, and treatment. By studying the aetiology, pathological basis, and clinical features of paediatric conditions, students will gain insights into the unique challenges of paediatric physiotherapy practice. The course also aims to equip students with the skills to assess children with various conditions effectively and develop comprehensive treatment plans tailored to individual patient needs.

topics: Review of basic physiological principles and dynamics of circulation
Heart physiology and cardiac cycle
ECG normal and abnormal
Thrombosis
Embolism
Thoracic outlet syndrome
Congenital heart deformities
Hypertensive heart disease
Corpulmonale
Congestive heart failure
Heart attack
Cardiac arrest
Ischaemic heart disease
Myocardial infarction
Principles of cardiac rehabilitation
objectives: Describe the aetiology, pathological basis, and clinical features of different cardiovascular conditions
Describe how to assess patients with different cardiovascular conditions
Outline treatment plans for different cardiovascular conditions
Explain the principles of cardiac rehabilitation
aim: PST424 aims to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of cardiovascular disorders and their management in the context of physiotherapy practice. By covering topics such as basic physiological principles, cardiac function, ECG interpretation, and specific cardiovascular conditions, students will gain the knowledge and skills necessary to assess and treat patients with cardiovascular disorders effectively. Additionally, the course aims to familiarize students with the principles of cardiac rehabilitation, emphasizing the importance of holistic care and long-term management for patients with cardiovascular conditions.

topics: Importance and central role of statistics in research
Review - types of variables, scales of measurement, concept of sampling, data collection
Reduction, summarization, and presentation of data
Probability
The Normal distribution
Sampling methods
Tests of hypothesis (significant difference, correlation, regression etc)
Parametric and non-parametric tests
objectives: Discuss the importance of statistics to research
Describe scientific methods of collating and summarizing data
Select and apply appropriate statistical tests for testing hypotheses
aim: PST425 introduces students to the fundamental principles and techniques of biostatistics, emphasizing their importance in research within the field of physiotherapy. By covering topics such as data collection, summarization, and statistical testing, the course aims to equip students with the necessary skills to analyze research data effectively and make informed decisions based on statistical evidence. Through a combination of lectures and practical exercises, students will develop a solid understanding of statistical methods and their application in physiotherapy research.

topics: The physiotherapist in a sports setting - relationship with athletes, coaches, other members of the sports medicine team, and other workers
Prevention of sports injuries - health education for athletes and coaches
Assessment of fitness of athletes - cardiopulmonary fitness, motor skill, anthropometric evaluation, etc.
Common injuries in different sports
Specific sports injuries - soccer, sprinting, long-distance running, jumper's knee, etc.
Physical management of sports injuries to facilitate quick recovery
Classification of sports injuries
Types and causes of sports injuries
Risk factors for injuries in sports
Teamwork in sports medicine
objectives: Discuss the roles of physiotherapy in sports medicine
Describe injuries associated with different sports
Outline a plan of management for the injured sportsman/woman
aim: PST426 provides students with a comprehensive understanding of the role of physiotherapy in sports medicine and the management of sports-related injuries. Through lectures and practical exercises, students will learn about injury prevention strategies, assessment techniques for athlete fitness, and the physical management of various sports injuries. By the end of the course, students will be equipped with the knowledge and skills to effectively work with athletes, coaches, and other members of the sports medicine team to optimize athlete performance and facilitate quick recovery from injuries.
